div1.p: Moran's autobiography gives a detailed account of the yellow fever experiments in which he took part.

div1.head: “The Story of John Moran ...,” by John Moran, [1937]
div1.p:
This autobiographical sketch was written for me by Mr. Moran
(at my request) and sent to me with his letter of July 24, 1937.

I was born in County Galway, Ireland, on March 15, 1876, coming to
the United States in early boyhood, residing in Youngstown, Ohio, until 1897.
Before I was yet 16 years of age, I had ambitions to become a medico. Lacking
the wherewithal, however, I compromised with myself by taking a commercial
course instead, with no intention of abandoning my goal. I was still young.
I decided to make a start by enlisting in the Hospital Corps of the U. S. Army
at the Hospital School of Instruction, Washington Barracks, Washington, D. C.,
completing the requisite six months' course there. Within a year after my
enlistment came the outbreak of the Spanish-American War. I was immediately
promoted from Private to Acting Hospital Steward (Sergeant), being ordered to
Cuba in January, 1899, where I served until the end of my term of enlistment,
being discharged from the Army, with EXCELLENT character, on July 2, 1900.
Automatically, I was appointed order clerk on the staff of General Fitzhugh Lee,
Commander of the Department of Western Cuba, with headquarters adjacent to Col-
umbia Barracks, today known as “Camp Columbia” and since the first days of the
Republic, the most imprtant garrison of the Cuban Army. While I was at General
Lee's headquarters, during July and August, two of the General's staff officers,
Majors Cartwright and Edmunds, were stricken with and succumbed to yellow fever.
The disease had assumed epidemic form among American soldiers and civilians in
the Provinces of Havana and Pinar del Rio, with a high rate of mortality. The
medical officers of the Army were nonplussed. General Geo. M. Sternberg, then
Surgeon General of the Army, decided that measures should be adopted to curb the
ravages of the dread disease. He appointed a Board of Officers, headed by Major
Walter Reed, Surgeon, U. S. Army, with Drs. James Carroll, Jesse W. Lazear and
Aristides Agramonte, as members, the latter a Cuban, “for the purpose of pursuing
scientific investigations with reference to the infectious diseases prevalent on
the Island of Cuba”. This Board was to be henceforth known as the Yellow Fever
Board and was frequently referred to as the Reed & Carroll Board, especially
during the time when the Board carried on its experiments at Camp Lazear, with
“infected bedding and clothing” and the “mosquito” theories. The Board had its
first meeting on June 25, 1900, at the Post Hospital, Columbia Barracks, and for the
following four months its activities were principally devoted to laboratory work,
with the object of discovering and isolating the yellow fever germ or microbe.
In the meantime two members of the Board were stricken with yellow fever, one
experimentally, the other accidentally, the latter being Dr. Jesse W. Lazear who
succumbed to the disease in September, 1900, and the former Dr. James Carroll
who purposely applied the “right” mosquito to his person. Dr. Carroll suffered
a severe attack of yellow fever, recovering within the usual course of the disease.
By this time Major Reed had arrived at the conclusion that the mosquito was the
culprit and that, in order to prove it, hitherto untried methods of experiment-
must be resorted to if the Board was to accomplish its mission. He was ready to
face the storm of protest which was sure to follow when his plan to use “human
guinea pigs” became known, and in this he was entirely correct. He was roundly
condemned, not only by the general public but by a very respectable percentage of
medical men as well. Playing with the lives of human beings, even for the sake
of humanity and science, was something unheard of. Realizing that he would not
be able to obtain “human guinea pigs” for his proposed experiments, unaccompanied
by a material reward or bonus, his next predicament was to find the “godfather”
who would supply the wherewithal. The Surgeon General of the Army, completely
in accord with him and his plan, had no funds at his disposal which could be
touched for such a purpose. Fortunately, General Leonard Wood, Military Govern-
or of Cuba, himself a medico, came to Major Reed's assistance, appropriating the
necessary amount out of Insular funds at his disposal. Major Reed then made it
quietly known among the troops stationed at Columbia Barracks, including the
members of the Hospital Corps, that he was “fishing” for volunteers for his yellow
fever experiments and that a handsome bonus - perhaps as much as $500 - would be
-- 2 --
paid to each such volunteer. Although I was then a civilian, I was permitted
by the Post Surgeon to retain the room I was occupying when I was discharged from
the service, Private John R. Kissinger of the Hospital Corps, who succeeded me in
the operating room, being my roommate. Dr. Roger Post Ames, Acting Assistant
Surgeon, on duty at the Post Hospital, knowing I was to enter the University of
Virginia next year, to start my medical course, accosted me one afternoon and told
me about Major Reed's quest and offer and remarking “There's a nice chance for you,
Johnny, to bolster your slim educational fund by $500” I agreed with him and told
him I would sleep over it. That evening I broke the news to Kissinger and he and
I talked over the matter. That $500. would be a great help for a man who expected
to study medicine for four years, with only sufficient for two years' tuition and
living expenses. Then, I thought the matter over from another angle. To start
off in medicine with such a noble act to my credit would be much more satisfying to
my self respect than if I should accept the money. Then again it was not at all
unlikely that I would go under. In such an event I did not much relish the idea
of having an epitaph reading something like this appear on my tombstone “Here lie
the remains of Johnny Moran who lost his life in a good cause and who spoiled it
through accepting AN INSIGNIFICANT REWARD OF $500”. In all truth I was not act-
uated so much by the benefits humanity might derive from my share in the proposed
tests as I was in the benefits my act might confer on medical science, although I
sensed that humanity and medical science in this case were synonymous and indivis-
able. I was a doctor in embryo. I had, of course, made up my mind to offer
myself for the experiments. Kissinger had made up his mind to do likewise. I
tried to dissuade him, pointing out that our motives wre entirely different and
that, after all, either of us had as good a chance of dying as we had of living
if the mosquito should prove to be the culprit in the transmission of yellow fever.
It was “Love's Labor Lost” so, having set my conscience at rest, I was very glad
to have his company. We would both volunteer for the experiments, no material
or money award to be involved. We let it go at that and turned out the lights
for a few hours' sleep. Next morning we walked across the parade grounds together
to Major Reed's room in the officers' quarters, your humble servant acting as spoke-
sman. Major Reed, upon learning our mission, was completely taken aback, his
surprise being further accentuated when he discovered that we were going in for the
experiments without a money award. Like the fine and amiable Virginian that he
was, he thanked us, accepting our offer conditional only upon passing a strict
physical examination, explaining to us that if the tests should prove successful
he wanted us to have a good fighting chance for recovery, that we could name any
doctor and nurse in the Army Medical Service in Cuba, in whom we might have most
confidence, to care for us if taken down with yellow fever, and that he would see
that they were ordered to Columbia Barracks for that purpose. We thanked him, at
the same time informing him that Dr. Ames and Mrs. Gillan would be acceptable to
us as doctor and nurse, the former having had experience in the treatment of yellow
at New Orleans, the latter being a graduate Army nurse. Throughout the years, it
has been repeatedly made of record that Major Reed, upon learning our mission,
stood to “Attention” and, suiting the action to the words, said “Gentlemen, I salute
you”. Neither was the salute executed nor the words spoken. I am personally in-
cline to believe that Major Reed was too much surprised at the time to think of it,
afterwards fathering the gesture and the words, thereby making it a matter of record.
The first time, to my knowledge, that it appeared in print was in Dr. Howard A.
Kelly's book “Walter Reed & Yellow Fever”, first published in 1906. Later, it
appeared in “Microbe Hunters” by Paul de Kruif and more recently in “Yellow Jack”
by Sidney Howard, the Playwright, and in many newspaper articles and editorials.

We took up residence in the Experimental Camp (Camp Lazear) on November
20th, 1900. I was installed in Major Reed's office tent, so used by him when he
visited and inspected the camp, twice daily. I acted as his secretary while
-- 3 --
awaiting my turn to be bitten. Virtually, we were all prisoners in the camp,
no one being allowed to leave and no visitors permitted except those invited by
a member of the Yellow Fever Board. During the period from November 20th to
December 25th, 1900, many of the “Notes” and papers on the progress of the
experiments, as well as personal letters to General Sternberg, all written by
or dictated to me by Major Reed, were typed by me. They were of an extremely
confidential nature at that time. Outstandingly impressed on my memory are the
letters Major Reed wrote to his chief, General Sternberg. I could sense the war
from high quaters waged against Major Reed and his mosquito theory, with Washington
as the base of operations. It can now be stated that one of the most bitter
opponents of Reed and the mosquito theory was the then Surgeon General of the U. S.
Public Health & Marine Hospital Service, with powerful ramifications of the same
Service in Cuba. That Service could see nothing than “infected bedding and clothing”
as responsible for the spread of yellow fever. In that Service there was one notable
exception, however, Dr. Henry R. Carter, connected with the quarantine service in
Cuba. He was a believer in the mosquito theory from the beginning.

The first attempt to inoculate me was made on November 26th, the second
on November 29th, mosquitoes confined in test tubes, tagged and identified, with
a complete record of their past activities, having been allowed to feed on me
from the inverted tubes. The results were NIL in each instance. Doctor Reed
then decided to reserve me for his master test, as he called it, to be carried out
in the mosquito building, then in process of construction. That building was
divided into two main sections, one section being insect proof and the other sect-
ion entirely unprotected against entry or exit of mosquitoes or other insects.
On December 21, 1900, fifteen mosquitoes were set free in the mosquito section
of this building, all of which had bitten severe cases of yellow fever from five
to twenty-four days before. At 12 Noon, five minutes after they were set free in
the room, I entered the compartment so that its fifteen guests might feed on me,
clad only in a night shirt which I removed upon entering, laying down on a disin-
fected hospital bed (the only furniture in the room) so that the guests might feed
on me without interruption. Major Reed provided me with a hand mirror so that I
might count the number of insects biting me. He was an interested observer on
the other side of the wire screen partition where two non-immune “controls” slept
for eighteen or twenty nights. My first visit to the mosquito room lasted twenty
minutes, during which seven insects fed on me, reentering the room again at 4:30
in the afternoon, being fed on by five mosquitoes. Next day, December 22nd, I
made my third and last visit to the mosquito room, at 4:30 P. M., and was bitten
by three mosquitoes. Therefore, by deduction, it was assumed that all fifteen
insects had fed on me. While awaiting results, Warren G. Jernegan, a volunteer
for the “infected bedding and clothing” test, offered to bet me five dollars that
I would not eat Christmas dinner at the Experimental Camp. True to the temper-
amental characteristics of those born in the Emerald Isle, I had to take him up.
Another volunteer held the stakes, two five-dollar gold pieces. Come what might,
I had made up my mind to win that bet, and I did win it. Dr. Ames informed me
previously that, given the existence of a healthy constitution, recovery from yellow
fever was likely, in nine cases out of ten, if recognized in time, total abstinence
from either food or drugs being essential once the fever set in, that those stricken
with yellow fever had unusually healthy appetites during the first hours of the
disease. From the date of my first visit to the mosquito room Major Reed had
instructed me to take my temerature three times daily and, should same deviate from
normal, to take it every hour, tracing same on my temperature chart. Nothing
happened until Christmas morning. I had slept like a top the night before and I
had eaten a hearty breakfast. About 10:00 A. M. I felt a flushing sensation in
my face and head. Temperature and pulse registered 100.4 and 88, respectively.
By 1:00 P. M., the hour scheduled for dinner instead of the usual noon hour, my
-- 4 --
temperature was 101.6 degrees F. Having made up my mind to win that bet, I
took good care that none of my camp companions should know I had “IT”. Being
in the office tent by myself, this was not very difficult. I responded to the
call for dinner at the mess tent, bluffed it through, eating very sparingly but
without attracting undue attention. Our Christmas dinner was a good one, con-
sisting of everything from turkey and cranberry sauce to oldfashioned Army “plum
duff” or plum pudding. The temptation to do it full justice was great but so
was the instinct for self preservation. Jernegan, who stood to lose five dollars,
was too busy enjoying the dinner to pay any special attention to my delicate
appetite and the small portions I served myself. Dinner over, I asked Jernegan
“How about that bet”. He replied “Guess you win”, adding “Dammit, you can't kill
an Irishman anyway”. After collecting the bet I told him that he had lost and
won at the same time. Looking at me tensely and full of concern, he said “You
don't mean to tell me that you have it, Johnny?” I answered in the affirmative.
Major Reed, who usually visited camp around 1:30 to 2:00 P. M. did not arrive until
after 3:00 P. M. They also had a Christmas dinner at the officers' mess at the
Post Hospital. When he did arrive my temperature was 103 and a fraction. He
came direct to the office tent and, after wishing me a Merry Christmas, inquired
if there was anything new. I pointed to the temperature chart on the field desk.
I venture to say that the smile of satisfaction on his face could not have been
broader had he been notified by the Secretary of War of his promotion to the rank
of Colonel. He gleefully rubbed his hands and said “Moran, this is one of the
happiest days of my life”. He had previously informed me that if the mosquito
house test should prove successful the mosquito theory would be established in
fool proof fashion and that the skeptics and diehards would not have a leg to
stand on. The mule-drawn ambulance which had brough Major Reed out to Camp
Lazear took me immediately to the special tent hospital established for the
experimental cases, within the Post Hospital grounds at Columbia Barracks. My
case of yellow fever was pronounced “very pretty” by Major Reed and his invited
guests of the medical fraternity, Major William C. Gorgas being one of those most
deeply interested. In ten days I was up and around, a little weak after my
siege of fever, pain and starvation. Drugs, in the treatment of yellow fever,
were contra-indicated. I was allowed cracked ice ad libitum, small sips of
strained watermelon juice, tablespoonful quantities of champagne, ice packs and
ice enemas, all intended to keep down the temperature and assist the kidneys in
functioning. My first real nourishment in a period of ten days was a teaspoonful
of milk. Two weeks after I became convalescent, I took the blood test from an-
other “pretty case” of yellow fever, aimed to determine whether or not an immune
could have a second attack. Results: NIL. I am confident that I am still immune.
I left Havana in February, 1901 and entered the University of Virginia in September
of that year, with visions of becoming an M. D. Though I lived economically at
the University, I soon realized that the amount of money I had saved for a four-
year course could barely be stretched out to cover
three years, so I was tempted to invest the major part of my educational fund in
an oil stock, swallowing the statements made by the promoters, hook, bait and sink-
er. Later, I had the satisfaction of knowing that I was “one of those born every
minute”. My hopes of becoming an M. D. vanished. I then went to New York and
was doing nicely in the insurance business, after two years of grilling work, when
Colonel Gorgas offered me a position as Sanitary Inspector on the Panama Canal.
Having had a taste of the tropics in Cuba, I could not resist the call. I served
on the Panama Canal from 1904 to 1915, resigning to go into business for myself in
the City of Panama. When the U. S. entered the World War, I set about disposing
of my business in order to enter the Service. By April, 1918, I had arranged my
affairs and made a beeline for Washington where, within forty-eight hours after
my interview with General Goethals, I was commissioned a captain in the Quarter-
-- 5 --
master Corps of the Army, General Goethals being at that time Assistant Chief of
Staff. General Gorgas, then Surgeon General of the Army, offered me a commission
in the Sanitary Corps of the Army but I had come to the conclusion that, being only
a “near doctor”, neither lemonade nor beer, I could render more efficient service
in the Quartermaster Corps than I could in the Sanitary Corps. While Generals
Goethals and Gorgas were never in harmony, except officially, while both were memb-
ers of the Isthmian Canal Commission, I enjoyed the friendship and confidence of
both. That personal relations between them, from the very beginning, were strained,
was no secret to those employed on the Panama Canal. They both had their fine
qualities and I hold the memories of both in reverence. Goethals built the Panama
Canal and Gorgas, putting in practice the Major Reed's discoveries, made it possible
to build the Canal with as little loss of life as possible from bubonic plague,
yellow fever and pernicious malaria, diseases which had practically nullified the
efforts of the French who originated work on the Panama Canal. I served overseas
with the AEF in France until the latter days of September, 1919, as Disbursing
Quartermaster, being honorably discharged from the Army at Governors Island, New
York Harbor, on October 1, 1919. I immediately entered the service of the Mercant-
ile Bank of the Americas, serving as branch manager in Venezuela for one of its
affiliates until December, 1921, when the depression of 1920-1921 caused the bank
to go into liquidation. In 1921, I accepted the position of manager with the
Mexican Trading Corporation, distributors in the Aztec Republic for Sun Oil Company
products and Firestone Tire & Rubber Company, resigning when the de la Huerta
revolution of 1923-24 broke out. I then came to Cuba but I returned to Mexico
and my previous position in 1926, severing my connection with Mexican Trading
Corporation, in February, 1928, to take over the Sun Oil Company representation
in Cuba. Here I have been ever since, making a passably decent living out of
petroleum and its products. Uncle Sam, with his monthly cheque of $125.00,
helps a lot towards allowing me to live comfortably and decently. While, through-
out the years, I was a perennial applicant for a Congressional medal of some kind,
from “leather” to “gold”, I nver applied, directly or indirectly, for a pension or
annuity on account of the part I took in the yellow fever experiments. When it
came to me unsolicited by the Act of February 28th, 1929, I accepted it. That Act
gave me a Special Gold Medal, $125.00 per month during the rest of my natural life
and to have my name placed on THE ROLL OF HONOR of the War Department to be publish-
ed each year in the Official Army Register. That ROLL will exist and be published
annually long after I have passed to my reward. There are 22 names on the ROLL
OF HONOR, as follows: the four members of the Yellow Fever Board and eighteen men
who volunteered for the experiments. Kissinger and myself volunteered without
material reward. The other sixteen accepted it. To have my name on the ROLL
means much more to me than do the medal and the annuity. I am also proud of the
following words of General Jefferson R. Kean, Medical Corps, U. S. Army, Retired,
who was Chief Surgeon on General Lee's staff here, at the time of the experiments:

General Kean's letters to Prof. James E. Peabody, under dates of
September 22, 1928, and October 1, 1928, respectively.

“As you have three pictures of Kissinger and one of Jernegan,
why don't you have a picture of Moran who was the real hero of
that bunch, the man who volunteered the same time as Kissinger,
who always refused to accept any gratuity and has always shown
a fine spirit of dignity and independence” Again “You ask whether
I think you are stressing Kissinger too much. I have no criticism
to make of your fine and generous enthusiasm for Kissinger, and
prefer to say that you have stressed Moran too little. He was
without doubt the fineest and strongest character of the group of
men infected at Camp Lazear, and my recollection is that he and
Kissinger volunteered at the same time”.
